node.title: Eating a lobster this Christmas? It may once have had feelings
node.alt: An octopus sits in a hole underwater as a diver swims past.
node.description: The UK has recognised decapods and cephalopodsÂ as 'sentient beings,' with animal rights advocates saying Australia should follow suit.
node.content:
["If you sit down to Christmas lunch next week and there's a lobster on the table, know that the deceased creature in front of you may once have had feelings.", "That's according to a recent announcement by the UK government, which recognised decapods (such as lobsters and crabs) and cephalopods (such as octopuses, squids and cuttlefish) as \"sentient beings.\"", "\"The science is now clear that decapods and cephalopods can feel pain,\" the UK's Animal Welfare Minister Zac Goldsmith said in a statement.", "", "
The UK government says\u00a0cephalopods \u2014 like these giant cuttlefish in South Australia\u00a0\u2014 are sentient beings.(Supplied: Jayne Jenkins)
", "While the move won't result in major changes to UK restaurants or households, it's a highly symbolic one, with animal rights advocates saying Australia should follow suit.", "
'Neglected' by animal welfare laws
", "The UK government is reforming its animal welfare laws in the wake of Brexit, including a bill that formally recognises certain animals as \"sentient beings.\"", "A sentient being is capable of experiencing a range of feelings or emotions, from negative ones like pain and suffering\u00a0to positive ones like pleasure, excitement and joy.", "The UK bill already stipulated that all vertebrates \u2013 animals with spines \u2013 are sentient beings. But last month, the UK government announced the bill would be amended to also include decapods and cephalopods.", "Jane Kotzmann, a senior lecturer in law at Deakin University and an expert on animal welfare laws, says the announcement was a big deal.", "\"Cephalopods and decapods are groups of animals that have generally been neglected by animal welfare laws,\" she tells ABC RN's Sunday Extra.", "\"So recognising that they are sentient in a very high profile way \u2014 by including them in those laws \u2014 I think is significant.\"", "The amendment followed a UK government-commissioned report from London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE), which reviewed 300 earlier studies and found strong scientific evidence that these creatures are sentient.", "The LSE report used a framework of eight different factors to determine sentience, including the existence of nociceptors\u00a0(pain receptors), and if the animals responded to pain relief medication.", "", "
An octopus builds an underwater home near the Sydney\u00a0suburb of\u00a0Mosman.(Supplied: Jayne Jenkins)
", "Researchers\u00a0found there was \"very strong evidence\" for sentience among octopuses in particular.", "This report is just the latest of many to show the complex behaviours of octopuses. For example, a 2018 study found that if octopuses were given the party drug ecstasy, they were increasingly sociable with one another.", "
What does this mean?
", "While the UK bill, which is yet to become law, is set to reclassify these animals as sentient, it will not mean any sweeping changes.", "The bill will not regulate the seafood or hospitality industries, but instead is \"designed to ensure animal welfare is well considered in future decision-making.\"", "\"It does do a bit [for animal rights], but certainly not enough,\" Dr Kotzmann says.", "", "
Divers meet a cuttlefish at Manly in Sydney.(Supplied: Jayne Jenkins)
", "\"[The bill] recognises animal sentience and establishes an animal sentience committee, which will be put in place to look at UK government policy and the implementation of policy \u2026 But they will only be looking at future policies and implementation of policy.\"", "\"So all the practices in relation to octopuses and so forth,\u00a0that have occurred in the past or that are currently being used, are not subject to question.\"", "This means current controversial practices like boiling lobsters alive or declawing crabs won't be changed in the UK, at least for the time being (although the LSE report heavily criticised these).", "\"Nevertheless, I think what's important about this recognition is, it's part of a growing trend of increasing welfare protections for animals. And not just a trend in legal terms, but also a trend amongst the public of growing awareness of animal sentience,\" Dr Kotzmann says.", "
What's the situation in Australia?
", "In Australia, different states and territories have very different animal welfare laws.", "In 2019, the ACT became the first and only jurisdiction to change the legal status of animals from \"property\" to sentient beings in their own right.", "The ACT reforms created broad protections for animals and also specific prohibitions on particular acts that cause cruelty to animals.", "And Victoria has committed to recognise animal sentience as the state reforms its animal welfare laws.", "Melina Tensen, a senior scientific officer at RSPCA Australia, says animal welfare legislation in every state and territory should include language around sentience.", "\"These feelings that we as humans experience throughout our lives, there are animals that are capable of having similar feelings.\"", "When it comes to decapods and cephalopods, many Australian jurisdictions don't even recognise them as animals, meaning they miss out on protections in existing animal welfare legislation.", "Decapods are not included within the definition of an animal in South Australia, Queensland, Tasmania and Western Australia.", "And cephalopods are not included within the definition of an animal in NSW, Victoria, the Northern Territory and Western Australia.", "", "
Two cuttlefish interact before mating, in the water\u00a0near the Sydney suburb of\u00a0Mosman.(Supplied: Jayne Jenkins)
", "Ms Tensen says Australia is \"obviously behind other jurisdictions overseas\" when it comes to regulations around the treatment of decapods and cephalopods.", "\"Things need to change and they need to change rapidly, particularly around Christmas time when a lot of people like to eat lobster,\" she says.", "
The power of consumers
", "Ms Tensen says if Australia is to take a similar approach to the UK around decapods and cephalopods, it's not only up to state and territory governments\u00a0but consumers.", "\"As consumers, we really have quite a bit of power, probably more power than we realise in terms of what we buy and what we choose not to buy,\" she says.", "\"So if we're looking to buy a lobster for Christmas, we need to make sure that the animal is dead before purchasing it.\"", "Ms Tensen says concerned Australian consumers should \"ask questions of the supplier: How has the lobster been killed? What sort of methods have been used? And express your concern if the method was not humane.\"", "\"The key is finding out how that animal has lived throughout its life, the extent of suffering and the extent to which suffering has been mitigated,\" she says.", "\"An informed consumer is a conscious consumer.\""]
